9.10.text:
Wills H. City, J.D.: Good afternoon and welcome
to the Live Wire, UNC Charlotte’s forum

14.29.text:
for conversations with news makers from here
on campus and beyond. I’m Wills H. City,

19.38.text:
J.D.: City. It’s happened to most of us
who’ve played a sport, gone to the gym,

23.64.text:
or are just sort of clumsy. You slipped chasing
a faster player, plant a leg funny on a treadmill,

29.40.text:
or tripped stepping off a curb. That ankle
turns and, before you know it, you’re on

33.48.text:
the ground. For a long time, ankle sprains
have been understood as a painful annoyance,

38.59.text:
something you can get over in a relatively
short time with ice and rest. But new research

42.85.text:
at UNC Charlotte is calling into question
the long-term effects of the injury. Doctor

46.93.text:
Dr. Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: Hubbard-Turner:
Hubbard-Turner is an Associate Professor in

49.65.text:
the Department of Kinesiology and UNC Charlotte
Athletic Training Coordinator. Her research

55.01.text:
on ankle sprains was featured by the New York
Times this week and she joins me in the studio

59.48.text:
today to discuss it. Dr. Hubbard-Turner, thank
you so much for joining us.

63.75.text:
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: Thank you for having
me.

64.74.text:
Wills H. City, J.D.: Now let’s start off.
Just give me a quick snapshot of some of the

68.58.text:
conclusions you were able to reach with this
research.

70.96.text:
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: The biggest in
terms of outcomes we have from our studies

75.34.text:
was seeing that when you have someone whether
it’s in a human or an animal model, who

80.90.text:
has either an acute or new ankle sprain, or
who has a history of ankle sprains, they’re

86.42.text:
less physically active. And so over time I
think a lot of folks think it’s just an

92.30.text:
ankle sprain, but that single ankle sprain
overtime can decrease activity levels and

98.92.text:
we also know decreased activity levels can
lead to a whole host of chronic disease development.

103.95.text:
And so I think now having this evidence that
really supports the fact that that acute ankle

109.35.text:
sprain or that long term ankle sprain can
really cause potentially bigger issues as

114.63.text:
the person ages.
Wills H. City, J.D.: Now before we get into

117.60.text:
the specifics of these two studies that you
recently conducted, let’s take a look at

121.72.text:
the structure of the ankle itself. Could you
just explain explain to me what happens when

126.95.text:
someone sprains their ankle?
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: Ok so by far the

130.72.text:
most common mechanism for an ankle sprain
is when someone – so if this is your foot

134.78.text:
– when you turn your ankle inwards, so to
invert or plantar flex the ankle, and what

140.86.text:
happens is on the outside or the lateral aspect
of your ankle you have three primary ligaments

145.89.text:
which stabilize the ankle joint and those
three ligaments – when the foot turns inward

151.38.text:
– are stretched and if that stretch goes
too far essentially what happens is those

156.27.text:
ligaments tear. And that tear can be anything
as small as like micro tearing so small tears

162.72.text:
to you know a full on tear where the entire
ligament is torn similarly to what we would

166.52.text:
think about when someone tears their ACL.
So there’s a variance in terms of the amount

171.42.text:
of damage that can occur when you have someone
that “rolls” their ankle.

175.43.text:
Wills H. City, J.D.: Sure and I was a little
bit surprised by how common these are in the

180.31.text:
percentages. Could you share some of those
numbers about just how common these injuries

184.29.text:
are?
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: If you look at

185.10.text:
all orthopedic injuries, ankle sprains are
the most common injury. So even though you

191.08.text:
may hear a lot about concussions, and ACL
tears, and those injuries are important and

196.54.text:
significant. But in terms of a day-to-day
basis, ankle sprains are the most common orthopedic

200.78.text:
pathology that we have.
Wills H. City, J.D.: Now many of these injuries

203.65.text:
are sports-related. I’m curious: what’s
the connection between some of the movements

208.91.text:
in the sports that we play and our ankles.
Are our ankles well adapted to be making some

214.13.text:
of these rapid lateral movements?
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: Not entirely. You

218.92.text:
know if you think about the ankle joint it
is a very small joint and it has to bear your

224.45.text:
total body weight and then when you look at
sports like football, basketball, soccer,

229.92.text:
volleyball, where you have lots of fast start,
stop, jumping maneuvers. And even if you have

236.84.text:
perfect field conditions you know sometimes
it’s just too much for the ankle to handle

241.38.text:
and so then it’s forcefully turned inward,
but then also you have times where you don’t

245.95.text:
have the best field conditions and it’s
not necessarily the ankle or the body it’s

250.09.text:
just they step in a hole. But no, they’re
things you can do to maybe help that but in

255.79.text:
terms of general you know it’s hard on the
ankle these sports and these activities.

260.42.text:
Wills H. City, J.D.: Chronic ankle instability
is a big part of these recent studies. Could

265.55.text:
you talk to me about that and its connection
to ankle sprains?

270.02.text:
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: So when someone
has an ankle sprain ideally what would happen

274.99.text:
is you would sprain your ankle, the ligaments
that surround the ankle that were sprained

279.60.text:
would heal and then you could go through like
a rehabilitation protocol to strengthen, to

286.09.text:
work on balance, and other things that become
impaired when you have any kind of joint related

290.82.text:
injury. But an estimated anywhere around typically
upwards of 70% of people who sprain their

297.03.text:
ankle end up not getting fully better and
so the development of chronic ankle instability

302.99.text:
occurs when they have that ankle sprain. Maybe
they don’t go through rehab or even some

309.07.text:
folks do go through rehab but they still have
instability so their ankle feels looser. They’ll

316.19.text:
report pain, sometimes they’ll say their
ankle feels weak, or probably one of the bigger

320.37.text:
complaints you’ll have is I feel like my
ankles gonna give out. So I go try to play

324.58.text:
basketball and when I go to run or jump I
feel like my ankle’s gonna give way. Or

329.45.text:
sometimes they’ll actually say my ankle
does give way and it almost feels like another

333.81.text:
ankle sprain in terms of kind of what they
had originally.

337.39.text:
Wills H. City, J.D.: Something else you and
your colleagues wrestle with in this research

342.75.text:
is the specific functional mechanism that’s
causing these problems in people with these

349.57.text:
ankle problems and you talk about ankle laxity
changes in neuro muscular skeletal control

356.34.text:
and then subjective fears that there’s something
wrong with the ankle. How hard is it to separate

362.16.text:
out what’s causing these issues for people
with ankle problems?

365.78.text:
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: It’s hard because
it’s obviously not going to be the same

368.36.text:
in everybody. I think one of the biggest things
we’ve seen in our lab as well as working

373.18.text:
with other researchers is it is it’s a mixture
of things there definitely seems to be people

379.28.text:
who sprained their ankle who they have this
laxity of looseness so you know when you feel

383.61.text:
and test the ankle there’s more motion and
then we also tend to see people who have these

390.33.text:
balance impairments. So you know you take
someone who has a history of ankle sprains

393.31.text:
and chronic ankle instability, they struggle
with maintaining balance or stance and those

399.73.text:
two things are gonna be somewhat interrelated
when you have damage to the ligament and that

403.84.text:
doesn’t heal you know you have nerves that
surround the ligament and those are damaged

407.95.text:
and if those don’t heal appropriately and
if the way the essentially the central and

413.10.text:
peripheral nervous system aren’t retrained
then we have these balanced alterations as

417.44.text:
well. And so they the kind of interact and
work together and some people have more of

420.96.text:
one and more of the other less of the other
and then you also have folks that you know

425.51.text:
exactly subjectively they will have a whole
host of symptoms they will talk about and

429.53.text:
limitations and then you have some that don’t
have as much and so there’s definitely a

433.91.text:
spectrum of injury and a spectrum of disability
when you have people who have ankle sprains

438.59.text:
and then chronic ankle instability development.
Wills H. City, J.D.: Let’s shift over to

442.50.text:
talking about some specifics about this research.
The title of your first study was An Acute

447.41.text:
Lateral Ankle Sprain Significantly Decreases
Physical Activity across the Lifespan. Now

452.96.text:
that first study was conducted on mice, how
did you come to that conclusion and just tell

458.02.text:
me what was happening in this study?
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: Well I’ve always

462.92.text:
had previously been involved in human related
research so you know you bring someone who

467.04.text:
has an ankle spilt ankle sprain and you measure
changes so subjective and more functional

472.21.text:
changes, but it came to a pint where I said
what’s really the bigger impact or what

478.73.text:
really is a bigger changes that occur with
an ankle sprain? And we have some great research

483.45.text:
and faculty here at UNC Charlotte that have
strong backgrounds in animal research and

489.37.text:
through kind of conversations and talking
it kind of came out that what if we looked

493.46.text:
at the animal model and we looked at a prospective
longitudinal study to really see what the

499.23.text:
effects are on of an ankle sprain springing
up across a lifespan. Obviously that research

504.91.text:
really can’t be done on a human and so what
we did was we just went and looked in the

509.92.text:
literature and found a way to essentially
sprain a ankle in a mouse model and then the

515.80.text:
next thing is the mouse anatomy is identical
to the human anatomy in terms of kind of how

520.54.text:
it looks from a ligament standpoint and then
once we sprain that the ligaments within the

525.57.text:
mice follow that mice along its natural lifespan
and measure physical activity every single

532.86.text:
day so all the mice had access to running
wheels. So it’s completely voluntary so

537.68.text:
if the mice didn’t want to run they didn’t
have to run. If the mice wanted to run and

541.96.text:
so every day we would have students that would
go down and they would record the distance

547.09.text:
and then the duration of that physical activity
and then we followed it until the natural

552.06.text:
end of the mice’s lifespan and we really
weren’t sure what we would find, we knew

556.87.text:
acutely so after we sprained the mice’s
ankle we were pretty confident that they would

561.77.text:
the mice that had essentially was we had a
group of mice that didn’t have a ankle sprain,

566.09.text:
we had a group of mice that had what we would
consider to be a minor ankle sprain, and then

570.30.text:
we had a group of mice that had a severe ankle
sprain and we knew acutely that the mice with

576.17.text:
the ankle sprains – both groups – would
probably be less physically active which is

579.34.text:
somewhat natural right? When you have an ankle
sprain, your ankle hurts there maybe some

583.18.text:
swelling and so you’re just not gonna wanna
run, but we figured maybe within four to six

590.06.text:
weeks that we would see that kind of go away
which we didn’t. Across the entire lifespan

596.25.text:
that mice with this severe ankle sprains are
significantly less physically active so they

600.40.text:
ran less compared to the mice with the minor
sprain as well as the no ankle sprain group

606.38.text:
but even the mice with a minor sprain they
were less physically active for most of the

611.26.text:
lifespan.
Wills H. City, J.D.: And this is a type of

612.78.text:
mouse that likes to be active right?
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: Right, correct.

615.10.text:
So these mice that we chose genetically their
bred to run, and we chose them on purpose

620.32.text:
because we kind of wanted as somewhat as much
as possible mimic an athletic recreational

626.09.text:
active person which most people who are participating
in sports they are driven to be active, and

631.82.text:
I think that they sprained their ankle and
they do have that drive to want to get back

634.96.text:
out to the sport or the activity. And so we
felt like we wanted to have a mouse that does

640.49.text:
want to run so even with that genetic predisposition,
they chose not to run.

646.05.text:
Wills H. City, J.D.: While I was browsing
the comments on your New York Times article

650.50.text:
which can be a dangerous thing to do no matter
what the topic is but I did see a few people

655.03.text:
raise the concern about some unnecessary suffering
of these mice, and then I referenced your

661.78.text:
study to kind of see what protocols were gone
through in that regard and there are pretty

669.21.text:
significant regulations and things being done
to make sure that these mice aren’t suffering

674.52.text:
forever…
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: Correct, right.

675.80.text:
So before we begin this study we have to go
through specific approval and that approval

681.02.text:
is vetted by a group of faculty as well as
a veterinarian that’s here on staff that

687.96.text:
reviews the protocol and their whole job is
to make sure animal welfare and health are

694.61.text:
really at the top priority. So when we did
the actually surgery to induce the ankle sprain

700.17.text:
the mice were under anesthesia, and then once
they were done with the surgery they were

705.32.text:
they were given similar to what a person would
take you know a pain-killing Tylenol type

709.44.text:
medicine but I can tell you those mice as
soon as they were up and awake and off the

715.91.text:
anesthesia you know they had a little limp
but honestly within two to three days with

721.04.text:
the exception of visually looking at their
ankle you would never know that they underwent

725.70.text:
surgery. So our research staff, as well as
the students that work on a research team,

731.66.text:
as well as the folks that are in charge of
and run the facility here, their their priorities

737.91.text:
making sure the animals are not in pain or
pain is minimized as much as possible and

742.90.text:
then the care afterwards is top notch so they’re
very well taken care of.

747.45.text:
Wills H. City, J.D.: I want to highlight a
selection from the discussion of this study

752.07.text:
that I found particularly interesting quote
“we are not aware of any other studies that

756.94.text:
have used other musculoskeletal injury models
and measured physical activity this lack of

762.22.text:
research on orthopedic injury and physical
activity is quite concerning” why?

767.13.text:
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: Physical inactivity
is one of the third biggest predicators of

771.48.text:
death and mortality in our country. You know
if you look at physical inactivity the host

777.18.text:
of chronic diseases you know from diabetes
to cardiovascular really to diseases pulmonary

782.55.text:
related you know the literature is so strong
and really showing and speaking to the impact

789.73.text:
physical inactivity can have on the overall
health and well-being and one thing we know

795.15.text:
physical inactivity physical inactivity excuse
me does decrease nationally over the lifespan.

799.56.text:
So as you age we are less active and part
of that’s right you have children, have

805.16.text:
a job, priorities change, but we know we have
a lot of activity early on usually due to

811.44.text:
sports and athletic participation and so it
was surprising we we know how common all these

816.45.text:
orthopedic injuries are. I mean you look at
college athletics professional sports but

821.66.text:
even amateur right and high school, and recreational
activities, you know we have all these injuries

826.70.text:
but we really don’t ever look at what happens
for five ten years down the line you know

833.13.text:
after that patient sprains their ankle or
even tears their ACL or you know has a shoulder

838.21.text:
injury, whatever they know the orthopedic
pathology will be is really trying to understand

842.26.text:
that long-term implication and that impact
it could have and not only activity but also

848.50.text:
well-being and mental health and all that
stuff.

850.70.text:
Wills H. City, J.D.: Sure. Moving to the next
study which was human base, who are you studying

855.53.text:
here and how did you take these measurements?
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: So we knew one

860.16.text:
of the bigger comments we would get you know
when people look at animal literature and

865.13.text:
say well its an animal it doesn’t necessarily
apply to me as a person so what we wanted

869.93.text:
to do is we wanted at least somewhat try to
assess and understand physical activity levels.

874.59.text:
So here at obviously we have this great huge
college population of students and so what

881.10.text:
we did is we wanted to recruit two group of
subjects folks who’ve never sprained their

885.68.text:
ankles before and no other history of any
kind of significant orthopedic injury. From

890.67.text:
an orthopedic standpoint there physically
healthy and then we wanted to recruit a students

895.46.text:
that have chronic ankle instability, so at
some point they sprain their ankle and then

900.26.text:
after that ankle sprain it never got better,
and so they complain of their ankle having

905.66.text:
pain or instability or giving way, and then
what we wanted to do was we gave them a pedometer

911.74.text:
that they would wear for seven consecutive
days and they would wear that throughout the

916.82.text:
day pretty much the only time they were allowed
to take it off is when they showered or at

920.45.text:
night time when they went to sleep and every
single day they had a check in with us to

924.68.text:
record and give us that their step count for
that day. We also have them fill out questionnaires

932.35.text:
which asset physical activity and try to get
a pretty good gauge of the you know step count

937.04.text:
is one thing, but also trying to understand
you know moderate vs vigorous physical activity.

942.76.text:
The time spent within that we even tried to
talk to them about time spent seated during

947.34.text:
the day, and we did this with both groups
but just trying to get at least a snapshot

952.72.text:
at one point in time what their activity levels
are. And we found that those with the history

961.49.text:
of chronic ankle stability or current chronic
ankle instability excuse me, there they were

966.42.text:
significantly physically less significant
less active in that time period compared to

971.66.text:
their healthy and those controls were matched
based on gender, as well as age, body weight,

977.70.text:
and height so we wanted to try to control
for as many extraneous variables as possible

984.40.text:
but there were significant less active and
they also had no less activity in terms of

988.30.text:
like vigorous activity so more exercise related
stuff cause obviously college students do

992.41.text:
walk a lot. So we wanted to try to understand
what they were doing activity wise.

997.21.text:
Wills H. City, J.D.: When read together with
your previous study is that strengthening

1000.87.text:
the conclusions that you had?
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: Yeah I think so

1003.37.text:
I think you know the the research that we’ve
done so far looking at now an animal model

1007.77.text:
as well as that study with the human model
and then now some of the other stuff we’re

1011.19.text:
doing is really starting to demonstrate that
even that single ankle sprain or that single

1017.07.text:
ankle sprain that may turn into an ankle instability,
has led to or is leading to a decrease in

1023.19.text:
physical activity levels.
Wills H. City, J.D.: We do have a read out

1027.70.text:
here of some of the things you were just mentioning,
but if you could just quickly go over some

1032.64.text:
of this and how it relates to what we were
just discussing?

1035.98.text:
Dr. Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: So you can
see that center of the table CAI the top stands

1041.57.text:
for chronic ankle instability and next to
that is the healthy group so those are the

1044.69.text:
means as well as the standard deviations.
So on average the group with the chronic ankle

1050.60.text:
instability was just taking around 6,600 steps
per day whereas the healthy subjects were

1055.42.text:
taking 8,800 steps per day, but then again
what we really want to look at to and you

1060.20.text:
go further down was a big portion of the day
was spent walking for both groups which again

1065.67.text:
isn’t surprising cause five of those days
were academic calendar days…

1069.24.text:
Wills H. City, J.D.: If you spent any time
on this campus you know…

1070.73.text:
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: It’s a big campus.
Wills H. City, J.D.: There’s some walking.

1072.77.text:
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: So we weren’t
surprised about that but we we’re surprised

1075.18.text:
again the difference and one that’s not
up here one of the things we asked the students

1079.68.text:
was about like bus use on campus because the
campus does have a very wide you know bus

1085.37.text:
service and you know the subjects that had
Chronic ankle instability subjectively reported

1089.34.text:
using the bus more, and so that would account
maybe for the last time spent walking. They

1094.42.text:
had more time spent seated and then also one
of the bigger things that we thought was important

1098.76.text:
was they spent less time doing both moderate
and vigorous activity. So it is really are

1102.95.text:
trying to capture the exercise component.
The groups of chronic ankle instability were

1106.70.text:
significantly less likely to do those types
of activities then the group of healthy subjects.

1112.50.text:
Wills H. City, J.D.: Does the data suggest
that chronic ankle instability affects this

1118.30.text:
moderate and vigorous activity more then just
walking is it clear on that?

1123.37.text:
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: No it’s not yeah
and we really didn’t try to separate those

1126.88.text:
two things out, but I think they’re definitely
appears to be a relationship with some with

1132.05.text:
some kind of the stuff we’re seen that especially
when you talk to these subjects and we give

1138.22.text:
them subject of questionnaires asking them
about the different symptoms, the activities

1143.41.text:
they feel they can do, so like you know when
does your ankle bother you the most during

1148.06.text:
like walking or running or jumping but then
also part of the questionnaires like going

1152.15.text:
up and down a flight of stairs, getting out
of bed more and those subjects with chronic

1156.30.text:
ankle instability consistently score lower
on those questionnaires. And the biggest issues

1161.90.text:
they always say is their ankle feels more
unstable or is more painful when they walk

1167.16.text:
when they run or when they jump and so I think
that’s why they are less likely and even

1171.25.text:
when you talk to them you’ll talk to plenty
of subjects who will say so I really used

1174.33.text:
to love playing basketball but I just cant
do that anymore because it really hurts my

1178.96.text:
ankle and I just really feel like I’m gonna
sprain it again so I don’t do that activity

1183.03.text:
anymore. And so I think they stay away from
those more moderate to vigorous activities

1188.35.text:
either secondary to their symptoms or a fear
of re-injury.

1191.03.text:
Wills H. City, J.D.: Sure and we’ve touched
on this concept of objective vs. subjective

1196.04.text:
ankle function, do you think that humans have
the chance of being affected more by by any

1203.77.text:
injury and we can talk about it in the context
of a ankle injury because of the added sort

1208.37.text:
of subjective dimension. Once we know we have
an injury we start being worried about it

1212.30.text:
and that can make the pain worse, make us
anticipate the injury, and aggravate something

1217.61.text:
else does that come into play?
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: For sure and that’s

1220.63.text:
one of the new areas that we really haven’t
examined a whole lot here at UNC Charlotte,

1224.43.text:
but there are some researchers that their
whole area is looking at fear avoidance or

1228.55.text:
fear of re-injury and looking at that and
there is a very large segment of the population

1234.27.text:
that you know have an injury maybe they do
have some symptoms and that then from a psychological

1239.97.text:
standpoint they really can’t return because
of that fear. So I definitely think that’s

1244.43.text:
part of it, and you know you talk to people
that subjectively report you know more symptoms

1248.22.text:
and some report less and sometimes those match
up when you do more objective data assessment

1253.94.text:
like are they really reporting that their
pain and their instability and then you take

1259.17.text:
your objective measurements and they match
and sometimes they don’t you know sometimes

1262.75.text:
you have that person that you know subjectively
reports it a lot more or less so which is

1268.42.text:
interesting you know that people definitely
report things sometimes differently than other

1272.05.text:
folks and you see it differently in like a
lab based setting.

1274.41.text:
Wills H. City, J.D.: There are some experimental
challenges that come along when studying humans

1279.50.text:
in the world rather animals in the lab…
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: Right

1281.66.text:
Wills H. City, J.D.: What are those and how
did you address it?

1283.98.text:
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: Well the great
thing about animal research is it is a very

1286.97.text:
controlled environment and when you do animal
research like for us when we did our study

1291.74.text:
you know genetically the mice are all identical
so you know can’t say that well maybe the

1296.54.text:
reason why I found this is because some of
them I said you know genetic predisposition

1300.56.text:
or they had a history of something or you
know there is other extraneous variables everything

1305.90.text:
is controlled. There all eating the same food,
they’re all in the same setting, same temperatures,

1310.60.text:
same water, so there’s no extraneous or
very little extreme state variables but obviously

1315.91.text:
with humans it’s very different you know
you have folks that do different activities

1320.99.text:
and report things differently and you know
it is hard to follow people long term because

1326.46.text:
you know they move especially in a college
setting they move, they graduate and so it’s

1331.30.text:
harder to control stuff so you know with the
human study there’s lot of stuff that could

1335.50.text:
influence that activity level over a seven
day period you know we tried to control some

1340.17.text:
of it you know we you know if someone got
sick let’s just say we had two subjects

1344.10.text:
that in the middle of that seven days they
got sick and so we threw them out because

1350.65.text:
obviously they’re gonna be less physically
active probably because they got sick, and

1356.45.text:
so you have to try to control for some of
that like we wouldn’t do it over any of

1359.07.text:
the holidays we wanted it to be a traditional
normal week and we would ask all the people

1364.39.text:
that before they started in a study both in
both groups you know is this a normal week

1368.68.text:
for you if not if you’re gonna be traveling
or if you have something going on. You know

1374.73.text:
we wanted to control at least somewhat for
that so ideally it really was a good picture

1380.24.text:
of what their normal everyday activity is.
Wills H. City, J.D.: So are there plans for

1384.56.text:
any other studies of this type?
Dr. Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: Yeah and now

1386.70.text:
we’re really excited you know with the animal
stuff we have a great team and we want to

1391.62.text:
try to look at some of the mechanisms behind
it so try to understand so what is happening

1396.64.text:
maybe at a more basic level that’s causing
this decrease activity you know is a lack

1402.02.text:
of healing is it something maybe with an inflammatory
response that’s not allowing healing to

1408.10.text:
occur so in looking at some of that stuff,
but then also look at two you know we have

1413.80.text:
the ankle sprain study to some of the mice
and all the mice had access to wheels three

1417.43.text:
days after injury and we choose three days
because normal inflammation typically resides

1422.61.text:
within three days so our thought was you know
that was really when the mice needed to be

1426.55.text:
resting because they had an active inflammation
and we know that if you do activity during

1432.03.text:
active inflammation that cant reside but maybe
they needed longer you know maybe if we had

1437.17.text:
a group that got them wheels seven days after
injury or even maybe two weeks after an injury

1442.70.text:
so they had more time to rest cause I think
that’s one of the bigger issues we see with

1446.17.text:
athletics is this drive to get kids back into
participation and so soon as pain goes away

1452.84.text:
you play again and maybe that’s part of
it is we’re not allowing to healing to appropriately

1457.39.text:
occur so we want to look at that. One of the
things we wanna look at an argument with human

1462.09.text:
subjects is looking at in addition to activity
levels is to look at overall health you know

1467.73.text:
look at things like you know body look at
composition cardiovascular function so to

1473.77.text:
see even at a younger age you know are these
students that are less active is that starting

1480.16.text:
to cause changes in terms of you know body
fat percentages overall kind of cardiovascular

1486.64.text:
health like to look at Bo2 max and those types
of measures. To kind of again continue looking

1491.11.text:
at that bigger picture in terms of how that
you know ankle sprain could potentially lead

1497.74.text:
to bigger issues.
Wills H. City, J.D.: In the few minutes we

1500.94.text:
have left I want to talk about prevention
and treatment. You mentioned that some of

1505.14.text:
these injuries are just unavoidable but are
there things that people can do to either

1510.26.text:
strengthen their ankle or in terms of footwear
is there anything that can be done?

1515.19.text:
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: Yes- there have
been a few good studies that have been shown

1518.76.text:
if someone has ankle instability so like I
said if someone sprained their ankle two years

1522.75.text:
ago five years ago, but now still today they
say my ankle feels unstable I have pain I

1528.25.text:
can’t do activities. Probably there’s
two really good things that they could do

1532.05.text:
one they can tape or brace their ankle. So
someone who has a history of ankle sprains

1537.38.text:
either taping or bracing has been shown to
be effective at helping stabilize the ankle,

1541.97.text:
of bracing being more effective because bracing
is typically more rigid and it stays tighter

1546.69.text:
for longer then tape but then the other big
thing they can do is participate or do some

1552.19.text:
form of a balanced training program and there’s
been a few studies showing that when you take

1556.90.text:
someone who has ankle instability and put
them in a four to six week balance training

1560.39.text:
protocol they get better and they not only
feel better subjectively but they’re less

1566.92.text:
likely to have chronic kind of symptoms and
problems. And the nice thing is it’s stuff

1573.07.text:
you can do at home like the exercises are
standing on one leg for 30 seconds and trying

1577.78.text:
to hold that position, and then you can make
it harder by closing your eyes or standing

1582.09.text:
on like a mini trampoline or even like a Bosu
ball something that’s unstable, and even

1588.47.text:
make it harder by standing on a unstable surface
and like reaching down and like picking up

1592.70.text:
a cone or if you don’t have a cone you know
put something on the floor and move it to

1597.64.text:
just really challenge the neuromuscular system.
It’s really effective. The other thing is

1603.34.text:
things like gaming systems like the Wii Fit
is a great tool that isn’t super expensive,

1610.87.text:
but the Wii Fit has games which are really
balanced orientated games and there’s been

1615.77.text:
some research showing that you know the Wii
Fit is really just as good as the fancy expensive

1621.28.text:
balance equipment we have in the research
lab and so its stuff that folks can do to

1626.19.text:
help get better and hopefully have less problems.
Wills H. City, J.D.: There seems to be some

1633.29.text:
conflicting reports about treatment. Are there
some solidly evidence-backed things that you

1641.54.text:
think people should do if they do sprain their
ankle?

1644.13.text:
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: First and foremost
they need to get treatment. I think the estimate

1648.08.text:
is somewhere just about fifty percent of people
who sprain their ankle never see any kind

1651.72.text:
of medical professional.
Wills H. City, J.D.: And I think that maybe

1653.70.text:
a misconception their treatments some people
believe that just put it on ice right yourself.

1658.88.text:
People should consult a professional?
Dr. Tricia Hubbard-Turner: Correct. You know

1663.03.text:
you want to protect the joint whether it’s
through some form of like an immobilization

1667.05.text:
or a wrap to allow healing to occur if you
have a limp you should be on crutches. You

1672.92.text:
know you ideally should see somebody about
it to make sure, one the see the severity

1677.06.text:
of it, but then two in order to get a referral
with most health care agencies you have to

1681.76.text:
have you know to get to a like physical therapist
lot of times you have to have a referral from

1686.05.text:
a physician. And so you really want to have
that initial kind of you know physician that

1693.61.text:
sees the injury, helps you understand, it
gives you that acute management whether be

1697.95.text:
like a brace, wrap a mobilization device to
allow healing to occur, and then from there

1703.80.text:
you are in a rehab protocol whether it’s
led by an athletic trainer or physical therapist.

1709.47.text:
You know where you go through exercises that
help get the motion back help, with strengthening,

1714.94.text:
help with balance, and then help with functional
exercise to help strengthen and help the nerves

1720.66.text:
you know function appropriately so that way
when they do return to activity they return

1725.47.text:
with a nice good strong healthy ankle. You
know I always like to say its analogies to

1730.51.text:
when someone you know you have an athlete
that tears their ACL, or sprains their MCL,

1736.87.text:
or has a shoulder injury, or even a concussion,
you know there’s a SET protocol that they

1741.16.text:
go through before they’re allowed to return
to play. Ankle sprains should be no different.

1745.59.text:
You know we should be seeking treatment and
rehab to get them back to where they can return

1751.65.text:
to participation vs. I think what happens
now you know even if they maybe see a physician

1755.93.text:
and do the ice and the rest as soon as pain
goes away they’ll start playing again and

1761.46.text:
the problem with that is the ligaments may
not be healed and the nerves and the muscles

1765.05.text:
may not be at the point where they can function
appropriately to prevent chronic joint injury.

1770.60.text:
Wills H. City, J.D.: Well, Dr. Hubbard-Turner,
that’s about all the time we have this week.

1774.02.text:
Thank you again for joining us. If you want
to see more of Dr. Hubbard – Turner’s

1778.72.text:
research on the long term effects of ankle
injuries check out the New York Times Well

1783.05.text:
Blog and you can find a full report. And tune
in next week here on the Live Wire: same time,
